conclusion: The problem involves finding the effective value of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in a rotating square coil in a uniform magnetic field.
The image shows a square coil labeled as 'abcd' with side length L, rotating around an axis OO' perpendicular to the magnetic field B. The side 'ab' is at a distance of L/4 from the axis.
The area of the square coil is calculated as A = L × L = L^2.

The induced EMF in a rotating coil is determined using Faraday's law of induction, which depends on the number of turns (N), magnetic field (B), area (A), angular velocity (ω), and the angle θ between the magnetic field and the normal to the coil.
The maximum induced EMF occurs when the coil is perpendicular to the magnetic field, and is given by \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = N B L^2 \omega \).
The induced EMF is sinusoidal in time, and the effective value (RMS value) of the EMF is given by \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{eff}} = \frac{\mathcal{E}_{\text{max}}}{\sqrt{2}} \).
The effective value of the induced EMF is calculated as \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{eff}} = \frac{N B L^2 \omega}{\sqrt{2}} \).
The position of the 'ab' side at a distance of L/4 from the axis does not affect the maximum or effective induced EMF, as these depend only on the area of the coil and the angle of rotation.
The final effective value of the induced electromotive force in the coil is \( \boxed{\frac{N B L^2 \omega}{\sqrt{2}}} \).
